title: Lesson 7: Understanding Ions - Cations, Anions, and Polyatomic Ions
content:
Lesson 7: Understanding Ions - Cations, Anions, and Polyatomic Ions

Meet the Charged-Up Atoms of Chemistry

You know what salt is. But did you know it's not made of atoms? It's made of something else...

It sounds strange, but it's true! While everything is built from atoms, the particles that make up table salt (sodium chloride) are not neutral atoms. They are special, charged versions of atoms called ions. This tiny electrical charge is a superpower that completely changes how atoms behave, allowing them to form a whole new range of compounds. Let's uncover the secret of these charged particles!

What is an Ion?

An atom is normally electrically neutral. It has an equal number of positive particles (protons) and negative particles (electrons). However, in a chemical reaction, an atom can gain or lose one or more electrons. When this happens, the balance is upset, and the atom gets an electrical charge.

An ion is an atom (or group of atoms) that has a net positive or negative electrical charge.

The Two Types of Ions: Cations and Anions

There are two types of ions, depending on whether they lose or gain electrons.

Cations (Positive Ions)

When an atom loses one or more negative electrons, it has more positive charges than negative ones. The result is a positively charged ion, called a CATION.

Example: Na → Na⁺ + e⁻

(A sodium atom loses one electron to become a sodium cation)

Anions (Negative Ions)

When an atom gains one or more negative electrons, it has more negative charges than positive ones. The result is a negatively charged ion, called an ANION.

Example: Cl + e⁻ → Cl⁻

(A chlorine atom gains one electron to become a chloride anion)

Memory Trick: Cations are "paws-itive," and Anions are negative.

Team Players: Polyatomic Ions

Sometimes, a whole group of atoms bonded together in a molecule can gain or lose electrons as a team. This charged group of atoms is called a polyatomic ion ("poly" means many). This group acts as a single unit in chemical reactions.

Example: The Sulphate Ion (SO₄²⁻)

This is a team made of one Sulphur atom and four Oxygen atoms.

The entire team has gained two extra electrons, giving the whole group a negative 2 charge.

Other examples include Ammonium (NH₄⁺) and Hydroxide (OH⁻).

Lesson Summary

CATION

A positively charged ion.
(Atom loses electrons)

ANION

A negatively charged ion.
(Atom gains electrons)

POLYATOMIC ION

A group of atoms that has an overall charge.

Ions are the charged particles that form the basis of many chemical compounds and reactions.
questions:
Lesson 7: Check Your Understanding

Q. 1 What is the main difference between a neutral atom and an ion?

Answer:

A neutral atom has a balanced electrical charge (equal number of protons and electrons). An ion is an atom that has gained or lost electrons, giving it an overall positive or negative electrical charge.

Q. 2 How is a cation formed? Does it have a positive or negative charge?

Answer:

A cation is formed when a neutral atom loses one or more electrons. Since it loses negative charges, it becomes positively charged.

Q. 3 How is an anion formed? Does it have a positive or negative charge?

Answer:

An anion is formed when a neutral atom gains one or more electrons. Since it gains extra negative charges, it becomes negatively charged.

Q. 4 Identify the following as a cation or an anion:
a) Ca²⁺
b) Cl⁻
c) O²⁻
d) Al³⁺

Answer:

  • Ca²⁺ has a positive (+) charge, so it is a cation.
  • Cl⁻ has a negative (-) charge, so it is an anion.
  • O²⁻ has a negative (-) charge, so it is an anion.
  • Al³⁺ has a positive (+) charge, so it is a cation.

Q. 5 What is a polyatomic ion? Give one example.

Answer:

A polyatomic ion is a group of atoms that are bonded together and act as a single unit with an overall electrical charge.

Example: The Sulphate ion (SO₄²⁻), the Nitrate ion (NO₃⁻), or the Ammonium ion (NH₄⁺).

Q. 6 The Ammonium ion has the formula NH₄⁺. How many atoms are in this ion, and what is its overall charge?

Answer:

  • Number of atoms: 1 Nitrogen (N) atom + 4 Hydrogen (H) atoms = 5 atoms total.
  • Overall charge: The '⁺' symbol indicates it has a charge of +1.

Q. 7 Table salt, NaCl, is made of charged particles. What are the names of the two ions that form it?

Answer:

It is formed by the positively charged Sodium ion (Na⁺) and the negatively charged Chloride ion (Cl⁻).

Q. 8 An ion is written as O²⁻. What does the "2-" tell you? Has this oxygen atom gained or lost electrons, and how many?

Answer:

  • The "2-" indicates that the ion has a negative charge of 2.
  • Because it is negative, the original oxygen atom must have gained electrons.
  • The number '2' means it has gained 2 electrons.

Q. 9 Is the Nitrate ion, NO₃⁻, an example of a cation, anion, or polyatomic ion? Explain.

Answer:

It is an example of both an anion and a polyatomic ion.

  • It's an anion because it has an overall negative charge (-1).
  • It's a polyatomic ion because it's made of a group of multiple atoms (1 Nitrogen and 3 Oxygen).

Q. 10 A magnesium atom (Mg) loses two electrons to become an ion. What is the correct way to write the symbol for this magnesium ion?

Answer:

Losing two negative electrons gives it a positive charge of 2. The symbol is written as Mg²⁺.
exercises:
Lesson 7: Practice Exercises

1 Is the Sulphide ion, S²⁻, a cation or an anion? Why?

Answer:

It is an anion because it has a negative charge.

2 A potassium atom (K) loses one electron. What is the symbol for the ion it forms?

Answer:

Losing one negative electron leaves it with a +1 charge. The symbol is K⁺.

3 Match the description to the correct term.

Description

1. A positively charged ion.

2. A negatively charged ion.

3. A charged group of atoms.

Term

A. Polyatomic ion

B. Anion

C. Cation

Answers:

1-C (Positively charged ion is a Cation)
2-B (Negatively charged ion is an Anion)
3-A (Charged group of atoms is a Polyatomic ion)

4 What does the symbol Al³⁺ tell us about the aluminium ion? (Two things)

Answer:

1. It is a cation (because of the positive charge).
2. The original aluminium atom has lost 3 electrons to get a +3 charge.

5 A calcium ion (Ca²⁺) and an oxide ion (O²⁻) are near each other. Will they attract or repel each other? Why?

Answer:

They will attract each other. The law of electrostatics states that opposite charges attract. The positive calcium ion will be attracted to the negative oxide ion.

6A nitrogen atom (N) gains three electrons to form an ion. What is the correct symbol for this ion?

Answer: N³⁻

Gaining 3 negative electrons gives the ion a charge of -3.

7Look at the Carbonate ion, CO₃²⁻. What is its charge and is it polyatomic?

Answer:

Its charge is -2. Yes, it is polyatomic because it is made of more than one atom (1 Carbon and 3 Oxygen).

8Which of these is a cation? Na, Na⁺, Cl, Cl⁻.

Answer: Na⁺

Cations are positively charged. Na and Cl are neutral atoms. Cl⁻ is an anion.

9What is the name of the positively charged ion formed from a Copper (Cu) atom?

Answer: The Copper ion.

10Name the polyatomic ion with the formula OH⁻.

Answer: The Hydroxide ion.

11How many atoms are in one Phosphate ion (PO₄³⁻)?

Answer:

1 Phosphorus (P) atom + 4 Oxygen (O) atoms = 5 atoms.

12A mystery particle is formed when a neutral atom gains an electron. Is this particle a cation or an anion?

Answer: Anion.

Gaining a negative electron gives the particle an overall negative charge, which is the definition of an anion.

13Look at the symbol for an Iron (II) ion: Fe²⁺. How many electrons did the original iron atom lose to form this?

Answer:

The "2+" charge indicates it lost 2 electrons.

14Do metals typically form cations or anions?

Answer: Cations.

Metals have a tendency to lose electrons, forming positively charged cations (e.g., Na⁺, Ca²⁺, Al³⁺).

15Calcium Oxide is an ionic compound made of Calcium ions (Ca²⁺) and Oxide ions (O²⁻). Is the net charge on the compound positive, negative, or neutral?

Answer: Neutral.

In an ionic compound, the total positive charge from the cations must balance the total negative charge from the anions. So, the overall net charge of the compound is always zero (neutral). (+2) + (-2) = 0.
intros:
Lesson 7: Understanding Ions - Cations, Anions, and Polyatomic Ions

Not all atoms are neutral! Sometimes they gain or lose a tiny particle, transforming them into charged particles with fascinating properties. Let's meet these "super-charged" atoms called ions.

The Givers and Takers

What happens when one atom gives something away, and another atom takes it?

Normally, atoms are neutral; they have a perfect balance of positive and negative charges inside them. But sometimes, in a chemical reaction, an atom might give away one of its tiny negative particles (an electron). When it loses a negative charge, the atom is no longer balanced—it becomes positively charged!

Likewise, an atom can take that electron. When it gains an extra negative charge, it becomes negatively charged. These charged atoms—both positive and negative—are no longer called atoms. They have a new name: ions. This simple act of giving and taking is the key to how many chemical compounds are formed.

An ion is an atom that couldn't stay neutral.

The Secret of Salt

How does a reactive metal (Sodium) and a toxic gas (Chlorine) combine to make something we eat every day (Salt)?


(Neutral) + ClChlorine atom
(Neutral) Na⁺ Cl⁻ Salt (NaCl)
Made of ions!

The answer lies in the formation of ions. When sodium (Na) and chlorine (Cl) meet, the sodium atom gives one of its electrons to the chlorine atom. The sodium atom becomes a positively charged sodium ion (Na⁺), and the chlorine atom becomes a negatively charged chloride ion (Cl⁻).

Just like opposite poles of a magnet, these positive and negative ions are now strongly attracted to each other. This attraction holds them together, forming the stable, harmless compound we know as table salt (NaCl). So, the "secret ingredient" in salt isn't atoms—it's ions!

Opposites attract, and in chemistry, they form compounds.

A Tale of Two Kittens

What's the difference between a Ca+ion and an Anion? Is there an easy way to remember?

It can be tricky to remember which is which, so here are a couple of silly tricks! An ion that loses electrons and becomes positively charged is called a CATION. Think of a cat. A cat has paws, and it's "paws-itive". So, a Cation is the PAWS-ITIVE ion!

An ion that gains electrons and becomes negatively charged is called an ANION. Think of 'An Onion'. Cutting an onion often makes you cry, which is a negative experience. So, an Anion is the NEGATIVE ion. Simple tricks like these can make learning chemistry much easier!

A Cation is a Paws-itive Cat, an Anion is like a Negative Onion.

Atoms with Superpowers

What happens when a normal atom gets a superpower? It becomes an ion!


(Cation) - Negative Ion
(Anion)

Think of a normal atom as a regular citizen—balanced and neutral. An ion is like an atom that has gained a superpower: an electrical charge! This charge gives it the special ability to be attracted to other charged particles.

If an atom loses negative particles, it gets a positive superpower (becoming a cation). If it gains negative particles, it gets a negative superpower (becoming an anion). This new power of attraction is what allows ions to stick together and form a huge range of materials, from the salt in our food to the minerals in rocks.

Ions are just atoms that got charged up!

The Charged-Up Team

Can a whole team of atoms have a charge? Yes! They're called polyatomic ions.


a single charge 3- PO₄³⁻

So far we've talked about single atoms gaining or losing electrons to become ions. But sometimes, a whole group of atoms that are already bonded together in a molecule can gain or lose electrons *as a team*. This charged-up team of atoms is called a polyatomic ion ("poly" means many).

For example, the phosphate ion (PO₄³⁻) is made of one phosphorus atom and four oxygen atoms that together have gained three extra electrons, giving the whole team a negative 3 charge. These charged teams act as a single unit in chemical reactions, just like a single-atom ion does.

Polyatomic ions: Teamwork makes the charge work.
summary:
Lesson 7 Summary

Understanding Ions

What is an Ion?

An ion is a charged particle that can be a single atom or a group of atoms with a net charge on them.

Ions are formed when neutral atoms or molecules lose or gain electrons. Compounds made of metals and non-metals often contain ions. For example, common salt (Sodium Chloride, NaCl) is made of positively charged sodium ions (Na⁺) and negatively charged chloride ions (Cl⁻).

Formation of Ions

Types of Ions at a Glance

Cations (Positively Charged)

Formed when an atom loses one or more electrons. Typically formed by metals.

Sodium: Na → Na⁺ + e⁻

Magnesium: Mg → Mg²⁺ + 2e⁻

Aluminium: Al → Al³⁺ + 3e⁻

Anions (Negatively Charged)

Formed when an atom gains one or more electrons. Typically formed by non-metals.

Chlorine: Cl + e⁻ → Cl⁻

Oxygen: O + 2e⁻ → O²⁻

Nitrogen: N + 3e⁻ → N³⁻

Polyatomic Ions

Sometimes, a group of atoms bonded together can have an overall charge. These are called polyatomic ions. They act as a single unit in chemical reactions.

Name Formula
Ammonium NH₄⁺
Hydroxide OH⁻
Nitrate NO₃⁻
Carbonate CO₃²⁻
Sulphate SO₄²⁻
Phosphate PO₄³⁻
